full_text:
Case 21-58, Document 39-2, 04/01/2021, 3068530, Page150 of 200

1    the resources available to her, it is practically impossible to
2    set financial bail conditions that could reasonably assure her
3    appearance in court.
4    
5    Even if the picture of her financial resources were
6    not opaque, as it is, detention would still be appropriate.
7    Personally, the defendant not only has significant financial
8    resources, but has demonstrated sophistication in hiding those
9    resources and herself.  After the arrest of Jeffrey Epstein,
10   Ms. Maxwell retreated from view.  She moved to New England,
11   changing locations on multiple occasions, and appears to have
12   made anonymous transactions both big and small.  The defense
13   said that she did all of this not to hide from the government
14   but to maintain her privacy and avoid public and press
15   scrutiny.  Even assuming that Ms. Maxwell only wanted to hide
16   from the press and public,  an assumption that the court does
17   not share, but even assuming that's the case, her recent
18   conduct underscores her extraordinary capacity to evade
19   detection, even in the face of what the defense has
20   acknowledged to be extreme and unusual efforts to locate her.
21   Because of these concerns, even a bail package with
22   electronic monitoring and home security guards would be
23   insufficient.  Were she to flee, the defendant could simply
24   remove the monitoring bracelet and, as other courts have
25   observed, home detention with electronic monitoring does not
26   prevent flight.  At best it limits a fleeing defendant's head

    SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C.
    (212) 805-0300

    DOJ-OGR-00020009

additional_notes: The document appears to be a court transcript or legal document related to the case of Ms. Maxwell. The text is typed and there are no visible handwritten notes or stamps. The document is well-formatted and legible.
